Award.AwardTitle: Energetic Phase Field Methods and Modeling in Biological Microstructures
Award.AbstractNarration: Wang<br/>DMS-0807915<br/><br/> During recent years, the energetic phase field approach has<br/>emerged as a successful modeling and simulation method with many<br/>advantages in studying microstructure evolutions. The idea of<br/>phase field methods is to introduce a set of phase field<br/>variables to implicitly track the moving surfaces of<br/>microstructures, which can be very complex and nonlinear. In<br/>this project, the investigator and his collaborators apply phase<br/>field methods to study biological microstructures, especially<br/>cell membranes. The project is mainly concerned with further<br/>analysis on phase field methods, and the broadening of<br/>applications in studying the evolution of biological<br/>microstructures for which phase field methods and related<br/>concepts can be used as a basis for more convenient or efficient<br/>treatments. The project includes modeling, numerical methods,<br/>and theoretical analysis. <br/><br/> The investigator studies some theoretic and algorithmic<br/>problems in phase field methods that still remain unsolved or<br/>partly unsolved today, such as asymptotic behavior of phase field<br/>variables (which is related to the De Giorgi conjecture), the<br/>consistency of the fluid coupled phase field model to the sharp<br/>interface model, topological information retrieval formulations,<br/>and convergence and acceleration of some popular algorithms. He<br/>also applies the theoretical results to the modeling and<br/>simulation of some complex microstructure systems, especially<br/>cellular adhesion and rolling in a shear flow, which can be used<br/>in the study of blood flows. Cell motility is another complex<br/>biological phenomenon that can be simulated using phase field<br/>models. Also considered is the simulation of acto-myosin driven<br/>cell oscillations, which can be applied to study cell division<br/>and migration, two of the most important functions of living<br/>cells. Besides simulating some observed phenomenon, phase field<br/>models can also be applied to predict details of some structures<br/>that are not yet fully known, such as highly folded membranes. <br/>
